awd_titl_txt: POSE: Phase I:  Tuitus - A sustainable, inclusive, open ecosystem for Natural Hazards Engineering
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is funded by Pathways to Enable Open-Source Ecosystems (POSE) which seeks to harness the power of open-source development for the creation of new technology solutions to problems of national and societal importance. Natural hazards, such as floods, landslides, earthquakes, tornadoes, and wildfires, threaten more than 57% of the US national infrastructure. Modeling these complex natural hazards pushes the frontiers of high-performance computing, multi-scale modeling, in-situ visualization, big-data analysis, and machine learning. Scientific software codes are often developed in an ad hoc manner by university researchers and graduate students with very little exposure to software development principles and practices. The robustness and open-source nature of these scientific codes are essential for the safety and security of the nation, its people, and the environment. The project establishes the Tuitus Foundation (Latin for “to protect or care for”), a sustainable, inclusive, open ecosystem of scientific codes for Natural Hazard Engineering (NHE). The project’s novelties are creating a unified interface that supports integration testing, research reproducibility, and workflow provenance in distributed computing environments. The project supports building scalable, automated testing and workflow management for high-performance computing (HPC) environments. The project tackles the social issues around building and sustaining a community by establishing a Governing Board of Directors and supporting community-driven software development in NHE. The project creates an inclusive community by offering guidelines and training for onboarding and supporting new developers through hackathons and Google Summer of Code. By auto-deploying thoroughly tested HPC software to the NSF-funded DesignSafe Cyberinfrastructure, the project impacts the broader community of 6,000 NHE researchers by making robust NHE codes immediately accessible. 

Open-source codes in NHE will significantly impact the decision-making process and regional-scale risk assessment. The integration of Tuitus Foundation’s HPC Continuous Integration/Continuous Delivery (CI/CD) service with DesignSafe creates a paradigm shift in open-source code delivery in NHE, improving real-world policy decisions during critical natural hazard events. The Tuitus Foundation adopts a holistic approach to address the critical technical challenges in the Open-Source Ecosystem (OSE) by offering a standard Application Programming Interface (API) for HPC and heterogenous hardware architectures and supporting a wide range of applications from HPC, machine learning, database schemas, Jupyter notebooks, and visualizations. This project is the first attempt to integrate HPC-scale CI testing with natural hazard engineering codes for multi-job pipelines. The Tapis framework provides programmable interfaces that enable developers to automate data management and job execution on HPC and cloud resources. Tapis OAuth2 provides a separate security layer for managing user credentials, allowing Tapis to access many different storage and computing resources on behalf of the user. HPC-scale CI/CD with theTapis API enables testing for extreme-scale problems on distributed computing environments and future exascale systems. The project offers workflow provenance in Jupyter notebooks by tracking workflows and packaging runtime environment, thus enhancing research reproducibility. The novel CI developments bring together literate programming and HPC testing to provide the much-needed robustness to improve trustworthiness in engineering decision-making.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Natural hazards like floods, earthquakes, and hurricanes threaten over half of U.S. infrastructure and cause billions in damages annually. The Tuitus project created an open ecosystem to support and improve the software tools engineers and scientists use to study and prepare for these hazards. Just as weather forecasting relies on sophisticated computer models, natural hazard engineering requires complex software to predict how buildings, bridges, and communities fare during disasters. However, these critical tools often lack proper testing and validation.


Over the past two years, Tuitus has made significant strides in establishing a sustainable natural hazard engineering software foundation. The project supported five widely used open-source tools that help engineers model phenomena like landslides, earthquake responses, storm surges, and ground failures. A major innovation was developing an automated testing system that can verify these complex programs work correctly when run on supercomputers—something not possible with standard software testing approaches. This system, built using the Tapis framework, ensures the reliability of tools that inform critical public safety decisions.


The project achieved several technical breakthroughs in improving natural hazard modeling capabilities. A notable advancement was the development of an inverse analysis method using differentiable graph neural networks for analyzing granular flows, which was published in Computers and Geotechnics. This innovation allows researchers to better understand and predict landslide behavior by automatically learning material properties from observed movements. Through the Google Summer of Code program, the project also developed new differentiable simulation capabilities that enable researchers to derive material properties directly from video observations of natural hazards - a significant step forward in connecting real-world observations with computational models.


Beyond the technical achievements, Tuitus focused on building an inclusive community of developers and users. The project organized multiple successful training events, including a computational academy that brought together 47 graduate students and researchers to learn advanced simulation techniques. Through Google Summer of Code, Tuitus mentored student developers who contributed valuable new features to the software tools. The project also established a vibrant outreach program, teaching basic programming concepts to over 225 kids aged 7-13 through partnerships with Austin public libraries, with a special focus on reaching underrepresented groups in STEM.


A particularly impactful initiative was a series of webinars and hackathons that drew participants from across the natural hazards engineering community. A Material Point Method webinar attracted 72 attendees eager to learn about advanced simulation techniques. At the PEARC'23 conference, we organized an in-person training session on our automated testing system for 28 participants, helping spread best practices for scientific software development. The hackathon events were especially successful, with 47 participants working on nine projects addressing real-world hazard challenges. The hackathon brought together domain experts, CI/CD specialists, software engineers, and social scientists to develop OSE codes that could benefit the broader community and help structure policy decisions during disaster events. These events helped forge connections between researchers, software developers, and practitioners while advancing the capabilities of open-source tools.


The intellectual merit of this work lies in pioneering new approaches for testing and validating complex scientific software that runs on high-performance computing systems while developing novel methods for connecting computational models with real-world observations. The automated testing framework developed by Tuitus represents a significant advance in ensuring the reliability of computational tools used in natural hazard engineering. This framework is now being integrated with DesignSafe, a major NSF-funded cyberinfrastructure platform thousands of researchers use.


The broader impacts of Tuitus extend from inspiring the next generation of scientists through youth outreach to improving the robustness of tools used for critical public safety decisions. The project has created a model for sustaining open-source scientific software through community engagement, automated testing, and inclusive governance. As natural hazards intensify due to climate change, the reliable computational tools and collaborative community fostered by Tuitus will be increasingly vital for protecting communities and infrastructure.
Looking ahead, Tuitus has laid the groundwork for expanding its impact through enhanced training programs, broader community participation, and continued technical innovation. The project demonstrates how strategic investment in open-source software infrastructure can advance scientific capabilities while building diverse and sustainable communities of practice around critical societal challenges.
